Claude Scientific Skills: 125+ Ready-to-Use AI-Powered Scientific Research Workflows

Dec 22, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Claude Scientific Skills: 125+ Ready-to-Use AI-Powered Scientific Research Workflows

Section titled “Claude Scientific Skills: 125+ Ready-to-Use AI-Powered Scientific Research Workflows”

In the rapidly evolving landscape of AI-assisted research, Claude Scientific Skills emerges as a game-changing toolkit that transforms Claude into a powerful scientific research assistant. Created by K-Dense-AI, this comprehensive collection of 125+ specialized skills enables researchers to leverage AI across diverse scientific domains without writing complex prompts from scratch.

What is Claude Scientific Skills?

Section titled “What is Claude Scientific Skills?”

Claude Scientific Skills is an open-source collection of ready-to-use scientific skills designed specifically for Claude. Each skill is a carefully crafted prompt template that guides Claude to perform specific scientific tasks with precision and domain expertise.

“Transform your Claude assistant into a specialized scientific research tool with just a few clicks.”

Key Statistics

Section titled “Key Statistics”
  • 125+ Scientific Skills covering diverse research domains
  • 26+ Scientific Databases integrated for data access
  • 54+ Python Packages recommended for scientific computing
  • 15+ Scientific Integrations with industry platforms
  • 20+ Real-World Workflows documented with examples

Core Features & Highlights

Section titled “Core Features & Highlights”

1. Comprehensive Domain Coverage

Section titled “1. Comprehensive Domain Coverage”

Claude Scientific Skills spans multiple scientific disciplines:

Bioinformatics & Genomics:

  • Sequence analysis and alignment
  • Variant calling and annotation
  • Gene expression analysis
  • Pathway enrichment studies

Cheminformatics & Drug Discovery:

  • Molecular property prediction
  • ADMET analysis
  • Chemical similarity searching
  • Compound library design

Proteomics & Structural Biology:

  • Protein structure prediction
  • Binding site analysis
  • Post-translational modification detection
  • Protein-protein interaction networks

Clinical Research:

  • Patient cohort analysis
  • Biomarker discovery
  • Clinical trial design assistance
  • Survival analysis workflows

Medical Imaging:

  • Image preprocessing pipelines
  • Feature extraction workflows
  • Radiomics analysis
  • Multi-modal image fusion

Machine Learning & AI:

  • Model selection guidance
  • Hyperparameter optimization
  • Feature engineering strategies
  • Experiment tracking workflows

2. Integrated Scientific Databases

Section titled “2. Integrated Scientific Databases”

Access 26+ databases directly through skills:

CategoryDatabases
LiteratureOpenAlex, PubMed, Semantic Scholar
ChemicalChEMBL, PubChem, DrugBank
BiologicalUniProt, Ensembl, COSMIC
ClinicalClinicalTrials.gov, PharmGKB
ProteinPDB, AlphaFold DB
PathwayReactome, KEGG

3. Python Package Ecosystem

Section titled “3. Python Package Ecosystem”

The skills recommend and integrate with 54+ scientific Python packages:

4. Industry Platform Integrations

Section titled “4. Industry Platform Integrations”

Connect with 15+ scientific platforms:

  • Benchling - Lab notebook and molecular biology
  • DNAnexus - Genomics data analysis
  • LatchBio - Bioinformatics workflows
  • OMERO - Microscopy data management
  • Protocols.io - Method sharing
  • Weights & Biases - ML experiment tracking

Installation Options

Section titled “Installation Options”

Option 1: Claude Code Marketplace (Recommended)

Section titled “Option 1: Claude Code Marketplace (Recommended)”

The easiest way to install:

  1. Open Claude Code
  2. Navigate to the Marketplace
  3. Search for “K-Dense-AI Scientific Skills”
  4. Click Install

Option 2: Cursor IDE

Section titled “Option 2: Cursor IDE”

For Cursor users:

  1. Open Cursor Settings
  2. Go to AI > Skills
  3. Add the K-Dense-AI repository
  4. Enable desired skills

Option 3: Manual MCP Client Installation

Section titled “Option 3: Manual MCP Client Installation”

For any MCP-compatible client:

After installation, configure your preferred databases and integrations:

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”

1. Skill Selection

Section titled “1. Skill Selection”
  • Choose the most specific skill for your task
  • Combine multiple skills for complex workflows
  • Start with exploratory skills before detailed analysis

2. Data Preparation

Section titled “2. Data Preparation”
  • Ensure data formats match skill requirements
  • Validate input data quality before analysis
  • Use recommended file formats (FASTA, PDB, CSV)

3. Result Validation

Section titled “3. Result Validation”
  • Cross-reference results with multiple databases
  • Verify computational predictions experimentally
  • Document assumptions and limitations

4. Workflow Documentation

Section titled “4. Workflow Documentation”
  • Save successful prompts for reuse
  • Track parameter choices and outcomes
  • Share workflows with team members

Troubleshooting & FAQ

Section titled “Troubleshooting & FAQ”

Q: Skills not appearing in Claude?

Section titled “Q: Skills not appearing in Claude?”

A: Ensure the MCP server is properly configured and restart Claude Code.

Q: Database queries returning empty results?

Section titled “Q: Database queries returning empty results?”

A: Check API keys are configured correctly and database services are accessible.

Q: Python code not executing?

Section titled “Q: Python code not executing?”

A: Verify required packages are installed in your environment.

Q: How do I create custom skills?

Section titled “Q: How do I create custom skills?”

A: Follow the skill template in the repository’s templates/ directory.

Q: Can I use skills offline?

Section titled “Q: Can I use skills offline?”

A: Yes, most skills work offline. Database queries require internet access.

Q: How often are skills updated?

Section titled “Q: How often are skills updated?”

A: The repository is actively maintained with regular updates for new databases and methods.

Recent Updates

Section titled “Recent Updates”

The project is actively developed with regular additions:

  • New Quantum Computing Skills - Qiskit integration for quantum chemistry
  • Enhanced ML Workflows - PyTorch Lightning support
  • Clinical Trial Tools - ClinicalTrials.gov deep integration
  • Improved Documentation - 20+ detailed workflow examples

Community & Support

Section titled “Community & Support”
  • GitHub Repository: K-Dense-AI/claude-scientific-skills
  • Documentation: docs/examples.md
  • Issues: GitHub Issues
  • License: MIT (Free and Open Source)

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Claude Scientific Skills represents a significant advancement in AI-assisted scientific research. By providing 125+ specialized skills with deep integration into scientific databases, Python ecosystems, and industry platforms, it transforms Claude from a general-purpose assistant into a powerful research partner.

Whether you’re a bioinformatician analyzing genomic data, a chemist searching for drug candidates, a clinician interpreting variants, or a data scientist building ML pipelines, Claude Scientific Skills provides the domain expertise and workflow guidance you need.

The project’s commitment to open-source development, active maintenance, and comprehensive documentation makes it an essential toolkit for any researcher looking to leverage AI in their scientific workflows. Start with a single skill, explore the documented workflows, and discover how AI can accelerate your research.

PromptHub: Open-Source Local-First AI Prompt Management Tool

Dec 22, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Are you tired of searching through notebooks, documents, and chat histories to find your AI prompts? PromptHub solves this problem elegantly - it lets you manage prompts like code with version control, variable templates, and multi-model testing, while keeping all your data stored locally for maximum privacy.

PromptHub is an open-source, free AI prompt management tool developed by legeling. Built with Electron, React, and TypeScript, it provides a modern desktop experience across macOS, Windows, and Linux platforms.

Key Features and Highlights

Section titled “Key Features and Highlights”

Comprehensive Prompt Management

Section titled “Comprehensive Prompt Management”

PromptHub offers a complete suite for organizing your AI prompts:

  • Create, Edit, and Delete - Full CRUD operations with intuitive interface
  • Folder and Tag System - Organize prompts with hierarchical folders and customizable tags
  • Favorites - Quick access to frequently used prompts
  • Full-Text Search - Search across titles, descriptions, and content
  • Multiple View Modes - Card, Gallery, and List views for different workflows

Version Control

Section titled “Version Control”

Never lose a good prompt again:

  • Automatic History - Every edit is automatically saved
  • Version Comparison - Side-by-side diff view for changes
  • Rollback Support - Restore any previous version with one click

Variable Templates

Section titled “Variable Templates”

Make your prompts dynamic and reusable:

When copying or testing, PromptHub prompts you to fill in the variables, making templates infinitely reusable.

Multi-Model AI Testing

Section titled “Multi-Model AI Testing”

Test your prompts across different AI models:

  • 18+ Providers Supported - OpenAI, Claude, Gemini, DeepSeek, Qwen, and more
  • Parallel Testing - Compare responses from multiple models simultaneously
  • Image Generation - Support for DALL-E and Stability AI
  • Result Persistence - Save test results with each prompt

Data Security and Privacy

Section titled “Data Security and Privacy”

Your data stays yours:

  • Local-First Storage - All data stored in local SQLite database
  • Master Password Protection - Application-level security
  • Private Folders - Encrypted storage for sensitive prompts (Beta)
  • Full Backup/Restore - Export everything in .phub.gz format
  • WebDAV Sync - Optional cloud sync with services like Nextcloud

Precautions and Troubleshooting

Common Issues

Section titled “Common Issues”

Application Won’t Start on macOS:

  • Run the xattr command mentioned in installation
  • Check System Settings > Privacy & Security

Database Corruption:

  • Use the backup feature regularly
  • Keep the .phub.gz backup file safe
  • Restore from backup if needed

AI Testing Fails:

  • Verify API key is correct
  • Check API endpoint URL
  • Ensure model name matches provider’s specification

WebDAV Sync Issues:

  • Verify WebDAV URL ends with correct path
  • Test connection in settings before enabling auto-sync
  • Check firewall/proxy settings

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: Is my data sent to any cloud service? A: No, all data is stored locally. WebDAV sync is optional and user-controlled.

Q: Can I share prompts with colleagues? A: Yes, export individual prompts or full backups in .phub.gz format.

Q: What happens if I forget my master password? A: Unfortunately, encrypted data cannot be recovered without the password.

Q: Does it work offline? A: The prompt management features work fully offline. Only AI testing requires internet.

Beads: A Memory Upgrade for Your AI Coding Agent

Dec 22, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Beads (bd) is a distributed, git-backed graph issue tracker designed specifically for AI coding agents. Created by Steve Yegge (former Google/Amazon engineer and renowned software blogger), Beads solves one of the most frustrating problems in AI-assisted development: the context window limitation.

When you start a new session with your AI coding assistant, it loses all understanding of your project goals and progress. Beads provides a persistent, structured memory that replaces messy markdown plans with a dependency-aware graph, allowing agents to handle long-horizon tasks without losing context.

Key Highlights

Section titled “Key Highlights”
  • Git as Database: Issues stored as JSONL in .beads/, versioned and merged like code
  • Agent-Optimized: JSON output, dependency tracking, and auto-ready task detection
  • Zero Conflict: Hash-based IDs prevent merge collisions in multi-agent workflows
  • Invisible Infrastructure: SQLite local cache with background daemon for auto-sync
  • Memory Compaction: Semantic summarization of old tasks to save context window

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”

Before installing Beads, ensure you have:

  • Operating System: Linux (glibc 2.32+), macOS, or Windows 11
  • Git: Version control system (for syncing and collaboration)
  • Go 1.24+ (optional, for building from source)

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

Quick Install (Recommended)

Section titled “Quick Install (Recommended)”

Package Managers

Section titled “Package Managers”

Section titled “MCP Server Installation”

Section titled “Verify Installation”

Section titled “Configuration”

Section titled “Initialize a Project”

Section titled “Agent Setup”

This adds approximately 1-2k tokens of context to your agent’s instructions.

Perfect for personal use on shared projects where you don’t want to affect team workflows.

Essential Commands

Section titled “Essential Commands”
CommandDescription
bd readyList tasks with no open blockers
bd create "Title" -p 0Create a P0 (highest priority) task
bd dep add <child> <parent>Link tasks with dependencies
bd show <id>View task details and audit trail
bd close <id>Mark a task as completed
bd syncForce immediate synchronization
bd compactSummarize old closed tasks
bd quickstartInteractive guide for AI agents
bd dep treeVisualize hierarchical relationships

  • Create and link tasks as it discovers work

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”

1. Use Hierarchical IDs for Epics

Section titled “1. Use Hierarchical IDs for Epics”

2. Leverage Dependency Types

Section titled “2. Leverage Dependency Types”

Beads supports four dependency types:

  • blocks: Task A must complete before Task B
  • related: Tasks are conceptually linked
  • parent-child: Hierarchical organization
  • discovered-from: Task found while working on another

Precautions

Section titled “Precautions”

Alpha Software Warning

Section titled “Alpha Software Warning”

Beads is currently in alpha (v0.9.x). While stable for development:

  • Avoid using in critical production systems until 1.0 release
  • Back up important data regularly
  • Report issues on GitHub

Git Dependency

Section titled “Git Dependency”

Beads relies entirely on Git for synchronization:

  • Ensure git push completes successfully before ending sessions
  • The “plane has NOT landed until git push completes”

Context Window Consideration

Section titled “Context Window Consideration”

While Beads reduces context consumption, complex queries can still use significant tokens. Use targeted queries (bd ready) rather than full dumps.

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: How is Beads different from GitHub Issues?

Section titled “Q: How is Beads different from GitHub Issues?”

A: Beads offers:

  • Typed dependencies with semantic meaning
  • Offline-first design with local SQLite
  • Git-native sync without external services
  • Hash-based IDs preventing multi-agent collisions
  • Agent-optimized output (JSON format)

Q: Can I use Beads offline?

Section titled “Q: Can I use Beads offline?”

A: Yes! All queries run against local SQLite. Sync happens via git push/pull when network is available.

Q: What about existing issue trackers?

Section titled “Q: What about existing issue trackers?”

A: Beads complements rather than replaces tools like Jira or GitHub Issues. Use Beads for AI agent memory and local development; sync important issues to your main tracker.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Beads represents a paradigm shift in how we think about AI coding assistants. Instead of treating them as stateless tools that forget everything between sessions, Beads gives them persistent, structured memory that grows with your project.

By leveraging Git’s familiar workflow, providing agent-optimized queries, and implementing intelligent memory compaction, Beads enables truly long-horizon task management. Whether you’re working solo or coordinating multiple AI agents, Beads ensures your coding assistants never lose track of the bigger picture.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

What if your AI assistant could not only understand your code but also execute commands, manage files, and work across your entire operating system? Desktop Commander MCP makes this possible, transforming Claude Desktop into a powerful, autonomous development partner that goes far beyond traditional IDE-focused AI tools.

Created by Eduard Ruzga (wonderwhy-er), Desktop Commander MCP is a Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that bridges Claude Desktop with your local system. With over thousands of weekly npm downloads and a growing community of enthusiastic developers, it’s rapidly becoming the go-to solution for developers who want AI-assisted development without the fragmentation of multiple tools.

Key Features and Highlights

Section titled “Key Features and Highlights”

🚀 Enhanced Terminal Control

Section titled “🚀 Enhanced Terminal Control”

Desktop Commander provides intelligent terminal integration with:

  • Smart process detection - Automatically knows when programs are ready for input
  • Interactive session management - Maintain long-running sessions (SSH, databases, dev servers)
  • Background execution - Run commands with timeout support
  • Process control - List, monitor, and terminate processes

📁 Comprehensive File Operations

Section titled “📁 Comprehensive File Operations”
  • Full filesystem access with intelligent permissions
  • Native Excel support (.xlsx, .xls, .xlsm) - read, write, edit, search
  • PDF capabilities - Extract text, create from markdown, modify existing PDFs
  • Surgical code editing - Search/replace blocks for precise changes
  • Pattern-based replacements with vscode-ripgrep integration
  • URL support - Fetch content from web resources directly

💻 In-Memory Code Execution

Section titled “💻 In-Memory Code Execution”

Execute code without saving files:

🔧 Configuration Management

Dynamic runtime configuration:

  • Blocked commands for security
  • Shell preferences (bash, zsh, PowerShell)
  • Directory access controls
  • File read/write limits

Known Limitations

Section titled “Known Limitations”
  1. Directory restrictions can be bypassed - Security through allowedDirectories is not absolute
  2. Terminal commands unrestricted - allowedDirectories only affects file operations
  3. File write limits - Default 50 lines per write to encourage efficient AI behavior

Common Issues

Section titled “Common Issues”

Claude times out:

  • Ensure MCP server is running
  • Check config JSON syntax
  • Restart Claude Desktop

Commands fail:

  • Verify shell path in configuration
  • Check command isn’t in blockedCommands
  • Ensure proper permissions

File access denied:

  • Add path to allowedDirectories
  • Verify file permissions on disk

Debug Mode

Section titled “Debug Mode”

For troubleshooting:

Connect debugger to Node.js process on port 9229.

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: Do I need API credits? A: No. Works with Claude Desktop Pro subscription ($20/month), not API calls.

Q: Does it auto-update? A: Yes, when installed via npx or Smithery, updates apply on Claude restart.

Q: Is my data collected? A: Limited pseudonymous telemetry only. No file contents or paths. Opt-out available.

Q: Can I use it with other Claude clients? A: Designed for Claude Desktop. Community adapters may exist for other clients.

What is Desktop Commander MCP?

Desktop Commander MCP is an open-source MCP (Model Context Protocol) server created by wonderwhy-er that enables Claude to:

  • Execute terminal commands with output streaming
  • Search and manage file systems
  • Edit files with surgical precision using diff capabilities

Section titled “Troubleshooting & FAQ”

Q: Commands are timing out

Section titled “Q: Commands are timing out”

A: Increase timeout in configuration or use background execution for long-running tasks.

Q: Permission denied errors

Section titled “Q: Permission denied errors”

A: Check directory access permissions in Desktop Commander configuration.

Q: Docker container not persisting data

Section titled “Q: Docker container not persisting data”

A: Use volume mounts (-v flag) for data persistence.

Q: Can’t find files with search

Section titled “Q: Can’t find files with search”

A: Ensure the search path is within allowed directories and try adjusting the search pattern.

Q: Updates not applying

Section titled “Q: Updates not applying”

A: For Options 1-4 and 6, restart Claude. For Option 5, run git pull && npm run setup.

Uninstallation

Section titled “Uninstallation”

Automatic (Recommended)

Section titled “Automatic (Recommended)”

Manual

Section titled “Manual”

Edit claude_desktop_config.json and remove the “desktop-commander” entry from mcpServers.

Community & Support

Section titled “Community & Support”
  • Website: desktopcommander.app
  • GitHub: wonderwhy-er/DesktopCommanderMCP
  • Discord: Join the Community
  • License: MIT (Free and Open Source)

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Desktop Commander MCP represents a paradigm shift in how we interact with AI assistants for desktop automation. By providing Claude with comprehensive terminal control, file system access, and native data file support, it transforms Claude from a conversational AI into a powerful automation partner.

Whether you’re a developer looking to streamline your workflow, a data analyst needing quick insights, or a system administrator automating routine tasks, Desktop Commander MCP offers the tools you need. Its active development, growing community, and commitment to open-source principles make it an essential addition to any Claude Desktop setup.

Claude Code System Prompts Revealed: Inside the AI That Powers Your Coding

Dec 21, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Discover the Hidden Architecture Behind Anthropic’s AI Coding Assistant

The Discovery

Section titled “The Discovery”

Ever wondered what makes Claude Code tick? Thanks to the open-source community, specifically the Piebald-AI/claude-code-system-prompts repository, we now have unprecedented visibility into the intricate system prompts that power one of the most popular AI coding assistants on the market.

This repository, maintained by the team behind Piebald, provides a comprehensive breakdown of all Claude Code’s various system prompts, updated with each new version. As of Claude Code v2.0.75 (December 20th, 2025), it covers 56 versions of changelog since v2.0.14.

Why Claude Code Has Multiple System Prompts

Section titled “Why Claude Code Has Multiple System Prompts”

Claude Code doesn’t just have one single string for its system prompt. Instead, there are multiple components working together:

Component TypeDescription
Conditional PromptsLarge portions added depending on environment and configs
Tool DescriptionsBuiltin tools like Write, Bash, and TodoWrite
Agent PromptsSeparate system prompts for Explore, Plan, and Task agents
Utility FunctionsAI-powered features like conversation compaction, CLAUDE.md generation

The result is 40+ strings that are constantly changing and moving within a very large minified JS file.

Key Prompt Categories

Section titled “Key Prompt Categories”

1. Main System Prompt (2,981 tokens)

Section titled “1. Main System Prompt (2,981 tokens)”

The core system prompt defines Claude Code’s fundamental behavior:

Communication Style:

  • Responses should be “short and concise” for command-line display
  • Uses GitHub-flavored markdown formatted for monospace fonts
  • Avoids emojis unless explicitly requested
  • Tools are for task completion only, not user communication

Technical Approach:

  • Prioritizes technical accuracy and truthfulness
  • Provides direct, objective technical info
  • Reads files before proposing modifications
  • Avoids over-engineering and unnecessary abstractions

2. Agent Prompts

Section titled “2. Agent Prompts”

Sub-agents

Agent Creation Architect1,111Creating custom AI agents with detailed specifications
CLAUDE.md Creation384Analyzing codebases and creating CLAUDE.md files
Status Line Setup1,310Configuring status line display

Section titled “3. Slash Commands”
CommandTokensPurpose
/pr-comments402Fetching and displaying GitHub PR comments

4. Utility Prompts

Section titled “4. Utility Prompts”

A2UI: Google's Agent-Driven Interface Protocol That Changes Everything

Dec 21, 2025
Vibe Sparking

From Text-Only Responses to Rich, Native UIs: How Google’s A2UI Protocol Enables AI Agents to Generate Interactive Interfaces

1. Introduction: Features and Highlights

Section titled “1. Introduction: Features and Highlights”

What is A2UI?

Section titled “What is A2UI?”

On December 15, 2025, Google publicly launched A2UI (Agent to UI), an open-source protocol that enables AI agents to generate rich, interactive user interfaces that render natively across platforms—without executing arbitrary code.

Think about it: instead of an AI agent responding with just text, it can now send back a complete, interactive form, a data visualization card, or a booking confirmation interface. The magic? Your app renders these UIs using native components, maintaining your design system while benefiting from AI-generated interfaces.

Core Problem Solved

Section titled “Core Problem Solved”

Traditional agent interactions face a fundamental tension:

ApproachProblem
Text-only responsesLimited expressiveness, tedious back-and-forth
HTML/JavaScript in iframesSecurity risks, sandboxing complexity, no native styling
A2UI approachDeclarative JSON data + native rendering = best of both worlds

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”
FeatureDescription
Security-FirstDeclarative data format (not executable code). Agents can only render pre-approved components from your catalog
LLM-FriendlyFlat component lists with ID references, easy for LLMs to generate incrementally
Framework-AgnosticWorks with React, Flutter, Angular, SwiftUI, Lit, and more
Transport-AgnosticCompatible with A2A, AG-UI, REST (experimental)
Progressive RenderingUsers see UI building in real-time as LLMs generate

Who’s Behind It?

Section titled “Who’s Behind It?”
  • Core Team: Google A2UI Team
  • Key Partners: CopilotKit/AG-UI (day-zero compatibility), Opal (core contributor), Gemini Enterprise
  • License: Apache 2.0
  • Current Version: v0.8 (Public Preview)

2. Prerequisites, Installation and Configuration

Section titled “2. Prerequisites, Installation and Configuration”

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”

Before getting started, ensure you have:

  • Node.js (for web clients and renderers)
  • Python 3.8+ (for agent samples)
  • Gemini API Key (for demo agents)
  • UV package manager (recommended for Python)

4. Precautions, FAQ, and Troubleshooting

Section titled “4. Precautions, FAQ, and Troubleshooting”

Important Precautions

Section titled “Important Precautions”
AreaRecommendation
SecurityOnly include components in your catalog that you trust. A2UI is declarative, not executable, but your renderer implementations must be secure
VersioningA2UI is v0.8 (Public Preview). Expect breaking changes before v1.0
PerformanceFor complex UIs, consider pagination and lazy loading in your renderer
AccessibilityYour renderer is responsible for accessibility. A2UI provides structure; you provide semantics

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: How is A2UI different from sending HTML?

A: A2UI sends structured JSON that describes UI components. Your app renders these using native widgets, maintaining your design system, accessibility, and security. HTML/JS requires sandboxing and can’t integrate with native styling.

Q: Can agents execute arbitrary code through A2UI?

A: No. A2UI is a declarative data format. Agents can only request components from your pre-approved catalog. Your renderer decides how to present them.

Q: Does A2UI replace MCP (Model Context Protocol)?

A: No, they’re complementary. MCP connects agents to tools and data. A2UI defines how agents describe UIs. You can use both in the same system.

Q: What about AG-UI?

A: AG-UI is the transport layer for real-time agent-UI communication. A2UI defines the payload format. They work together beautifully.

Q: Is A2UI production-ready?

A: A2UI is v0.8 (Public Preview). It’s functional but evolving. Production use should plan for specification updates.

Troubleshooting

Section titled “Troubleshooting”

Problem: Agent responses not rendering

Solution: Ensure your agent’s output matches the A2UI schema with proper delimiters.

Problem: Components not appearing

Solution: Verify the component type is in your catalog:

Problem: Data binding not updating

Solution: Check that your data model is properly initialized and the bind paths are correct:

5. Collaboration with Similar Products and Comparative Analysis

Section titled “5. Collaboration with Similar Products and Comparative Analysis”

The Agentic UI Protocol Landscape

Section titled “The Agentic UI Protocol Landscape”

In 2025, three complementary protocols have emerged as the foundation for agent-driven interfaces:

ProtocolPurposeCreatorFocus
A2UIDeclarative UI descriptionsGoogleWhat UI to render (payload)
MCPAgent-to-tool connectionsAnthropicHow agents access tools (vertical)
AG-UIReal-time agent-UI communicationCopilotKitHow UIs receive updates (transport)
A2AAgent-to-agent communicationGoogleHow agents talk to each other (horizontal)

A2UI vs MCP-UI Comparison

Section titled “A2UI vs MCP-UI Comparison”
AspectA2UIMCP-UI/MCP Apps
PhilosophyNative-first: “Blueprint” for native componentsWeb-first: HTML/JS in sandboxed iframes
RenderingApp renders using native widgetsBrowser renders sandboxed web content
StylingInherits host app stylingIsolated styling in sandbox
Security ModelComponent catalog restrictionIframe sandboxing
Cross-PlatformSame payload works on web, mobile, desktopPrimarily web-focused
Backed ByGoogleAnthropic, OpenAI

How They Work Together

Section titled “How They Work Together”

Comparative Analysis with Opal

Section titled “Comparative Analysis with Opal”

Opal (also from Google) uses A2UI as its underlying protocol:

  • Opal provides higher-level abstractions for AI mini-apps
  • A2UI provides the wire protocol for UI descriptions
  • Together they enable “one-sentence AI apps”

When to Use What

Section titled “When to Use What”
ScenarioRecommended Protocol
Native mobile app with AI featuresA2UI + AG-UI
Web chat with rich responsesMCP Apps or A2UI
Multi-agent orchestration with UIA2UI + A2A + AG-UI
Tool-calling with data accessMCP
Cross-platform consistencyA2UI

Roadmap

Section titled “Roadmap”

The A2UI team has prioritized:

  1. Specification stabilization (v1.0)
  2. React renderer (official support)
  3. Jetpack Compose and SwiftUI (native mobile)
  4. REST transport (production-ready)
  5. Integration with Genkit and LangGraph

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

A2UI represents a fundamental shift in how AI agents interact with users. Instead of text-only responses or risky code execution, agents can now describe rich, interactive UIs that render natively across platforms.

Key Takeaways:

  1. A2UI is declarative - It describes UIs, not executes code
  2. Security by design - Component catalog restricts what agents can request
  3. Framework-agnostic - One agent response works across web, mobile, desktop
  4. Composable - Works alongside MCP, AG-UI, and A2A for complete agent systems

As the agentic era accelerates, protocols like A2UI will become essential infrastructure for building AI applications that feel native, secure, and responsive.

Ready to build with A2UI? Start with the official quickstart or explore the GitHub samples.

Hugging Face Skills: Fine-Tune Any Open-Source LLM with Natural Language

Dec 21, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Turn Conversations Into Fine-Tuned Models — No ML Expertise Required

What Are Hugging Face Skills?

Section titled “What Are Hugging Face Skills?”

Hugging Face Skills is a revolutionary system that enables AI coding agents like Claude Code, OpenAI Codex, and Google Gemini CLI to fine-tune open-source language models end-to-end through natural language conversations.

Instead of writing complex training scripts, configuring GPU resources, and managing deployment pipelines manually, you simply describe what you want in plain English:

The AI agent handles everything else: data validation, hardware selection, script generation, job submission, progress monitoring, and model publishing.

Key Features and Highlights

Section titled “Key Features and Highlights”

End-to-End Automation

Section titled “End-to-End Automation”
CapabilityDescription
Data ValidationAutomatically checks dataset format compatibility before training
Hardware SelectionIntelligently picks the right GPU based on model size and budget
Script GenerationCreates production-ready training scripts with TRL library
Job SubmissionSubmits training jobs to Hugging Face cloud GPUs
Real-time MonitoringTracks progress via Trackio dashboard
Model PublishingPushes finished models to Hugging Face Hub
GGUF ConversionConverts models for local deployment with llama.cpp/Ollama

Supported Training Methods

Section titled “Supported Training Methods”
MethodBest ForExample Dataset
SFT (Supervised Fine-Tuning)Quality behavior examplesCustomer support conversations
DPO (Direct Preference Optimization)Preference-annotated dataChosen/rejected response pairs
GRPO (Group Relative Policy Optimization)Verifiable success criteriaMath problems, coding tasks

Precautions, FAQ, and Troubleshooting

Section titled “Precautions, FAQ, and Troubleshooting”

Frequently Asked Questions

Section titled “Frequently Asked Questions”

Q: What’s the minimum cost to try this?

A: A demo run on 100 examples with t4-small costs approximately $0.30-0.50.

Q: Can I train models larger than 7B?

A: The current HF Skills system supports up to 7B. For larger models, use full Hugging Face infrastructure.

Q: Which dataset formats are supported?

A:

  • SFT: messages column with conversation format
  • DPO: chosen, rejected, and optionally prompt columns
  • GRPO: Dataset with verifiable correct answers

n8n-skills: Build Flawless n8n Workflows with Claude Code

Dec 21, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Transform Your n8n Workflow Development with AI-Powered Skills

What is n8n-skills?

Section titled “What is n8n-skills?”

n8n-skills is a collection of 7 complementary Claude Code skills designed to teach AI assistants how to build production-ready n8n workflows using the n8n-mcp MCP server.

Created by Romuald Członkowski from AI Advisors, these skills solve the common challenges developers face when building n8n workflows programmatically.

Why n8n-skills Exists

Section titled “Why n8n-skills Exists”

Building n8n workflows programmatically can be challenging. Common issues include:

ChallengeHow n8n-skills Helps
Using MCP tools incorrectlyExpert guidance on tool selection
Validation error loopsValidation error interpretation and fixing
Unknown workflow patterns5 proven architectural patterns
Node misconfigurationOperation-aware node configuration
Expression syntax errorsCorrect {{}} patterns and variables

The 7 Skills

Section titled “The 7 Skills”

1. n8n Expression Syntax

Section titled “1. n8n Expression Syntax”

Teaches correct n8n expression syntax and common patterns.

Activates when: Writing expressions, using {{}} syntax, accessing $json/$node variables.

Key Features:

  • Core variables ($json, $node, $now, $env)
  • Critical gotcha: Webhook data is under $json.body
  • Common mistakes catalog with fixes
  • When NOT to use expressions (Code nodes!)

2. n8n MCP Tools Expert (HIGHEST PRIORITY)

Section titled “2. n8n MCP Tools Expert (HIGHEST PRIORITY)”

Expert guide for using n8n-mcp MCP tools effectively.

Key Features:

  • Tool selection guide (which tool for which task)
  • nodeType format differences (nodes-base.* vs n8n-nodes-base.*)
  • Validation profiles (minimal/runtime/ai-friendly/strict)
  • Smart parameters (branch=“true” for IF nodes)
  • Auto-sanitization system explained

3. n8n Workflow Patterns

Section titled “3. n8n Workflow Patterns”

Build workflows using 5 proven architectural patterns.

Key Features:

  • 5 proven patterns (webhook processing, HTTP API, database, AI, scheduled)
  • Workflow creation checklist
  • Real examples from 2,653+ n8n templates
  • Pattern selection guide

4. n8n Validation Expert

Section titled “4. n8n Validation Expert”

Interpret validation errors and guide fixing.

Key Features:

  • Validation loop workflow
  • Real error catalog
  • Auto-sanitization behavior explained
  • False positives guide

5. n8n Node Configuration

Section titled “5. n8n Node Configuration”

Operation-aware node configuration guidance.

Key Features:

  • Property dependency rules (e.g., sendBody → contentType)
  • Operation-specific requirements
  • AI connection types (8 types for AI Agent workflows)

6. n8n Code JavaScript

Section titled “6. n8n Code JavaScript”

Write effective JavaScript code in n8n Code nodes.

Key Features:

  • Data access patterns ($input.all(), $input.first(), $input.item)
  • Correct return format: [{json: {...}}]
  • Built-in functions ($helpers.httpRequest(), DateTime, $jmespath())
  • Top 5 error patterns with solutions (covering 62%+ of failures)
  • 10 production-tested patterns

7. n8n Code Python

Section titled “7. n8n Code Python”

Write Python code in n8n Code nodes with proper limitations awareness.

Key Features:

  • Important: Use JavaScript for 95% of use cases
  • Critical limitation: No external libraries (requests, pandas, numpy)
  • Standard library reference (json, datetime, re, etc.)
  • Workarounds for missing libraries

FAQs & Troubleshooting

Section titled “FAQs & Troubleshooting”

Q: Why does my webhook workflow fail?

Section titled “Q: Why does my webhook workflow fail?”

A: Remember that webhook data is under $json.body, not directly in $json. This is the most common gotcha.

Q: How do I choose between Code node JS vs Python?

Section titled “Q: How do I choose between Code node JS vs Python?”

A: Use JavaScript for 95% of use cases. Python has critical limitations:

  • No external libraries (requests, pandas, numpy)
  • Only standard library available

Q: Validation keeps failing with false positives

Section titled “Q: Validation keeps failing with false positives”

A: Use appropriate validation profiles:

  • minimal for quick checks during development
  • runtime for production-ready validation
  • Check the auto-sanitization behavior

Q: Which MCP tools should I use first?

Section titled “Q: Which MCP tools should I use first?”

A: Follow this order:

  1. search_templates - Check if templates exist
  2. search_nodes - Find required nodes
  3. get_node - Get configuration details
  4. validate_node - Validate your config
  5. validate_workflow - Final check

Gemini CLI Conductor: Context-Driven Development That Plans Before It Codes

Dec 21, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Benjamin Franklin once said: “Failing to plan is planning to fail.”

This wisdom applies perfectly to AI-assisted coding. While tools like ChatGPT and Claude excel at answering questions, they often fall short when it comes to complex, multi-session projects where context gets lost between conversations.

Enter Conductor - a game-changing extension for Gemini CLI that introduces Context-Driven Development. Instead of treating AI interactions as fleeting chat logs, Conductor helps you create formal specifications and plans that live alongside your code as persistent Markdown files.

What is Conductor?

Section titled “What is Conductor?”

Conductor is a preview extension for Gemini CLI that transforms how you work with AI on code projects. Its core philosophy is simple but powerful:

“Treat context as a managed artifact alongside your code.”

Rather than depending on impermanent chat logs, Conductor helps you:

  • Create formal specifications before writing code
  • Maintain persistent context across sessions
  • Build implementation plans that guide the AI’s behavior
  • Keep your repository as the single source of truth

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”

1. Plan Before Implementation

Section titled “1. Plan Before Implementation”

Conductor enforces a structured workflow: Context → Spec & Plan → Implement. This ensures you think through requirements before diving into code.

2. Persistent Context Files

Section titled “2. Persistent Context Files”

All project context is stored in Markdown files that:

  • Survive beyond individual chat sessions
  • Can be version-controlled with Git
  • Enable team collaboration with shared standards

3. Hierarchical Task Organization

Section titled “3. Hierarchical Task Organization”

Work is organized into a clear hierarchy:

  • Tracks - High-level work units (features, bug fixes)
  • Phases - Major stages within a track
  • Tasks - Individual implementation steps

4. Brownfield-Friendly

Section titled “4. Brownfield-Friendly”

Unlike many AI tools that struggle with existing codebases, Conductor excels at “brownfield” development - working with mature projects where architectural nuance matters.

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

Getting started with Conductor is straightforward:

The --auto-update flag ensures you always have the latest version.

Prerequisites:

  • Gemini CLI installed and configured
  • Git repository initialized
  • Node.js (for Gemini CLI)

Commands Reference

Section titled “Commands Reference”

Conductor provides five core commands:

CommandPurpose
/conductor:setupInitial project configuration (run once per project)
/conductor:newTrackBegin a new feature or bug fix
/conductor:implementExecute planned tasks
/conductor:statusView current progress
/conductor:revertUndo work logically (tracks/phases/tasks, not commits)

Pro Tip: Add a description to newTrack: /conductor:newTrack "Add user authentication"

The Context-Driven Workflow

Section titled “The Context-Driven Workflow”

Step 1: Setup Your Project

Section titled “Step 1: Setup Your Project”

Run /conductor:setup to establish your project’s foundational context:

This creates configuration files for:

  • Product Definition - Users, goals, features
  • Tech Stack - Languages, frameworks, databases
  • Workflow Preferences - TDD approach, commit strategies
  • Code Style Guides - Formatting, naming conventions

Step 2: Create a New Track

Section titled “Step 2: Create a New Track”

When starting new work, create a track:

This generates:

  • spec.md - Detailed requirements document
  • plan.md - Actionable task breakdown with phases

Step 3: Review Before Implementation

Section titled “Step 3: Review Before Implementation”

Critical: Conductor requires human review of plans before implementation begins. This is your chance to refine requirements and catch issues early.

Step 4: Implement

Section titled “Step 4: Implement”

Execute the plan:

Conductor will work through tasks systematically, maintaining state so you can pause and resume across sessions.

Generated File Structure

Section titled “Generated File Structure”

After setup, your project will include:

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”

1. Run Setup Once Per Project

Section titled “1. Run Setup Once Per Project”

The setup command establishes shared team standards. Run it once, then commit the generated files.

2. Review Plans Carefully

Section titled “2. Review Plans Carefully”

Plans require human approval before implementation. Take time to refine them - it’s much cheaper to fix a plan than to refactor code.

3. Monitor Token Usage

Section titled “3. Monitor Token Usage”

Context-heavy operations consume more tokens. Use /stats model to track consumption.

4. Use Logical Revert

Section titled “4. Use Logical Revert”

The /conductor:revert command reverts based on tracks/phases/tasks rather than Git commits, providing safer rollbacks.

5. Maintain Context Files as Living Documentation

Section titled “5. Maintain Context Files as Living Documentation”

Your conductor files aren’t just for AI - they’re valuable documentation for your team.

Conductor vs. Other AI Tools

Section titled “Conductor vs. Other AI Tools”
FeatureStandard Chat AIConductor
Context PersistenceSession-onlyPermanent files
PlanningOptionalEnforced
Team CollaborationCopy-paste chaosShared configs
Brownfield SupportLimitedExcellent
State ManagementNoneBuilt-in checkpoints

vs. Amazon Q Developer Transform

Section titled “vs. Amazon Q Developer Transform”

While both are AI-powered, they serve different purposes:

  • Conductor = Project manager for day-to-day coding
  • Amazon Transform = Large-scale migrations (e.g., Java 8 → Java 17)

vs. Cursor/Claude Code

Section titled “vs. Cursor/Claude Code”

Conductor complements rather than replaces IDE-integrated AI:

  • Use Conductor for planning and specification
  • Use Cursor/Claude for in-editor implementation

Real-World Scenarios

Section titled “Real-World Scenarios”

Scenario 1: New Feature Development

Section titled “Scenario 1: New Feature Development”

Scenario 2: Bug Fix with Investigation

Section titled “Scenario 2: Bug Fix with Investigation”

Scenario 3: Team Onboarding

Section titled “Scenario 3: Team Onboarding”

New developer joins? They can:

  1. Read conductor/product.md for product context
  2. Review conductor/tech-stack.md for technical decisions
  3. Check conductor/workflow.md for conventions
  4. Start contributing immediately with consistent guidelines

Troubleshooting

Section titled “Troubleshooting”
IssueSolution
Extension not foundEnsure Gemini CLI is updated to latest version
Setup failsCheck you have write permissions in the repository
Context too largeUse /stats model to monitor; consider splitting work
Plan generation slowLarge codebases may require patience during analysis

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: Does Conductor work with existing projects?

Section titled “Q: Does Conductor work with existing projects?”

A: Yes! Conductor is specifically designed for “brownfield” development. The setup command analyzes your existing codebase to understand patterns.

Q: Can I edit generated plans?

Section titled “Q: Can I edit generated plans?”

A: Absolutely. Plans are Markdown files - edit them as needed before implementation.

Q: Is my code sent to Google?

Section titled “Q: Is my code sent to Google?”

A: Conductor uses Gemini API. Review Google’s AI terms and your organization’s policies.

Q: Can I use Conductor with other AI tools?

Section titled “Q: Can I use Conductor with other AI tools?”

A: Yes. The generated specs and plans are valuable input for any AI assistant.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Conductor represents a paradigm shift in AI-assisted development. By treating context as a first-class artifact and planning as a mandatory step, it addresses the core weakness of chat-based AI coding: loss of context and lack of structure.

Key takeaways:

  • Plan first, code second - Conductor enforces specification before implementation
  • Context is king - Persistent files ensure nothing gets lost between sessions
  • Team-ready - Shared configurations enable consistent AI interactions across developers
  • Brownfield-capable - Works with your existing codebase, not against it

The future of AI coding isn’t just about generating code faster - it’s about generating the right code, consistently. Conductor is a significant step in that direction.

  • Conductor GitHub Repository
  • Gemini CLI Official Repository
  • Spec-Driven Development with Gemini CLI - Medium

BMAD Installation & Configuration Guide: Best Practices for Project-Level Setup

Dec 20, 2025
Vibe Sparking

BMAD (Build More, Architect Dreams) is an AI-driven agile development methodology framework that integrates multiple AI Agents, workflows, and modules. It supports 18+ IDEs including Claude Code, Codex, and Cursor. This guide walks you through the complete installation and configuration process for BMAD v6.0.0-alpha.

1 | Why Project-Level Installation?

Section titled “1 | Why Project-Level Installation?”

Key Recommendation: Install BMAD in your project directory, NOT in your user home directory.

Benefits:

  • Isolation: Each project has independent BMAD configuration
  • Version Control: Project-level config can be tracked with Git
  • Team Collaboration: Team members get identical configs when cloning
  • Multi-Project Support: Different projects can use different BMAD versions

BMAD v6 Installation Update: Modularization + AgentVibes “talking” dev experience

Dec 15, 2025
Vibe Sparking

The core changes in v6 are a rebuilt directory/artifact system plus voice (AgentVibes) formally integrated into the BMAD workflow.

1) Bottom line first: the two most tangible changes from v4 to v6

Section titled “1) Bottom line first: the two most tangible changes from v4 to v6”

Change A: the directory moved from “single core” to an engineering structure of “Core + Modules + Manifests.” In the v4 user guide, personalization preferences (tech stack, naming rules, etc.) were managed at .bmad-core/data/technical-preferences.md.

In v6 (Alpha), the official positioning is “Agent-as-Code + reproducible pipelines,” with an explicit workspace anatomy: .bmad/ stores profiles/blueprints/runs and other traceable artifacts.

Change B: AgentVibes is treated as the first-party experience layer: letting BMAD agents speak in Claude Code, switch voices, and be controlled by slash commands / MCP. AgentVibes’ official description is blunt: it was originally built to “add voice” to Claude Code and offers both MCP (natural-language control) and slash commands.

2) Directory structure: v4 “.bmad-core” vs v6 “.bmad + modules + artifacts”

Section titled “2) Directory structure: v4 “.bmad-core” vs v6 “.bmad + modules + artifacts””

Breaking it down based on the installation log

v4 (common mental model for users)

Section titled “v4 (common mental model for users)”
  • Core directory: .bmad-core/ Stores preferences, data, templates; for example, the v4 user guide clearly points to .bmad-core/data/technical-preferences.md for preferences.
  • Web bundle workflow: dist/teams/... The typical move is to copy dist/teams/team-fullstack.txt into a web UI/Claude/GPT as a “team prompt.”
  • Feels like a “prompt framework + directory convention.” Engineering-wise it works, but “traceable/reproducible outputs” were not the primary goal.

v6 (what your installation shows)

Section titled “v6 (what your installation shows)”

From the log, the most important “on-disk” changes are:

  • Root directory unified at <project>/.bmad (yours: /Users/vsai/.../vs-ai-agents/.bmad)
  • Modular installation: Core + bmb + bmgd + bmm + cis
    • Core: installs core agents (e.g., bmad-master.md)
    • bmb: Builder/Factory (the “factory” for custom agents, workflows, modules)
    • bmm: Method (Analyst/PM/Dev/SM/UX, the full team)
    • bmgd: Game Dev (and vendors cross-module workflows)
    • cis: Creative Innovation Suite

At the same time, it makes a few things explicit that weren’t very visible in v4:

  • Compiles/generates artifacts (manifests): the log literally reports “61 workflows, 21 agents, 5 tasks, 1 tools…” — evidence that v6 is leaning into “versionable/traceable” outputs (much more engineered). That matches the v6 Alpha emphasis on “reproducible, auditable, diffable.”
  • Sprint artifact directory becomes an installation-time setting: you chose docs/sprint-artifacts, and the installer created it (handy for teams running agile).
  • Custom extension directories are explicitly separated
    • bmad-custom-src: custom agents/workflows
    • bmad-custom-modules-src: custom modules
      This essentially forces separation of “official modules” and “custom assets” for easier upgrades/merges.
  • Sidecar memory directory: the log also replaced {agent_sidecar_folder} → {project-root}/.bmad-user-memory (typically for agent “sidecar memory/run traces,” aligning with v6’s artifact-centric approach).

v4 is more “prompt framework + directory convention”; v6 is more “agent engineering system with build artifacts and traceable assets.”

3) AgentVibes integration: the key upgrades from “usable” to “pleasant”

Section titled “3) AgentVibes integration: the key upgrades from “usable” to “pleasant””

The most attention-grabbing part of the log is this:

  • Installer showed “AgentVibes TTS Injection Summary”
  • Injected TTS into .../.bmad/core/agents/bmad-master.md
  • Backups stored at ~/.bmad-tts-backups/
  • Then launched the AgentVibes installer, dropping slash commands, TTS hooks, personality templates, background music, etc., into the project’s .claude/

This matches AgentVibes’ official description closely:

What problem does AgentVibes solve?

Section titled “What problem does AgentVibes solve?”
  • It provides MCP (natural-language control): assistants don’t have to memorize slash commands; you can just say “switch to the Aria voice.”
  • It also provides slash commands (zero token cost) like /agent-vibes:list, /agent-vibes:switch Aria.
  • Multi–TTS-provider abstraction: Piper, macOS Say, ElevenLabs are all supported in the same capability layer (your log shows the macOS Say fast-install path).
  • The installer explicitly states it will put commands/hooks/personalities/plugins into .claude/.

Why does this matter for BMAD v6?

Section titled “Why does this matter for BMAD v6?”

Because v6 targets “multi-agent, multi-workflow, multi-artifact,” humans’ attention gets fragmented across lots of process info. TTS brings two benefits:

  1. Stronger state feedback: start/finish cues are audible — no need to stare at the screen.
  2. Stronger sense of roles: switching PM/SM/Architect/Dev roles feels more like a team (AgentVibes’ BMAD integration highlights this).

4) Summary for moving from v4 to v6

Section titled “4) Summary for moving from v4 to v6”

  1. Plan how to migrate v4 preferences v4 preferences live at .bmad-core/data/technical-preferences.md. v6 emphasizes workspace + policies + manifests (the structure under .bmad/). Recommendation: keep the v4 preference content as “team conventions,” then gradually map it to v6’s profile/policy system (avoid a one-shot forced migration that loses meaning).

  2. Put “custom assets” into the two directories you’ve configured

  • agents/workflows → bmad-custom-src
  • modules → bmad-custom-modules-src
    This reduces conflicts when upgrading v6 alpha/beta later.
  1. Default to “slash commands first” for AgentVibes AgentVibes also notes: MCP is convenient but consumes context tokens; slash commands are cheaper. In other words: use /-commands for daily work, then fall back to natural-language MCP occasionally for a balanced experience and cost.

Detailed log

Section titled “Detailed log”

  • BMAD

Breaking the "No-Device Repro" Challenge: How Antigravity Pinpoints Complex Bugs Through Code Reasoning

Dec 11, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Breaking the “No-Device Repro” Challenge: How Antigravity Pinpoints Complex Bugs Through Code Reasoning

Section titled “Breaking the “No-Device Repro” Challenge: How Antigravity Pinpoints Complex Bugs Through Code Reasoning”

In software development, few things frustrate engineers more than this: “the user has a problem, but I can’t reproduce it here.”

Especially when specific hardware, specific user roles, or specific network environments are involved, reproducing the issue often requires pricey devices or complex environment setup. As an intelligent coding agent, Antigravity demonstrates a new approach: without physical devices, use pure code reasoning and full-chain data validation to precisely locate and fix the bug.

This article reviews a recent real case (Issue #181: abnormal records appearing when a doctor views patient data) to walk through this “blind” problem-solving process.

Challenge: An Unseen Site

Section titled “Challenge: An Unseen Site”

Problem description: A hospital doctor unexpectedly saw other patients’ records while using a PC/tablet to view a specific patient’s data.

Difficulties:

  1. No environment: The dev environment cannot connect to the hospital intranet, and cannot log in to that doctor’s account.
  2. No device: The specific device used by the doctor is unavailable.
  3. Limited info: Only one screenshot and a short line: “During rounds, I saw someone else’s data.”

Traditional practice would be: borrow an account, find a device, connect to the intranet, and try to reproduce. If reproduction fails, the bug often gets shelved.

Antigravity’s Problem-Solving Mindset: Logic Over Visuals

Section titled “Antigravity’s Problem-Solving Mindset: Logic Over Visuals”

Antigravity cannot “see” the screen, but it can see through the symptoms to the code essence. The core is three steps: full-chain tracing -> code archaeology -> data falsification.

Step 1: Full-Chain Tracing (UI to Database)

Section titled “Step 1: Full-Chain Tracing (UI to Database)”

Since the UI cannot be operated, read how the UI is built.

  1. Frontend locating: By searching the keyword records.json and analyzing the frontend code patient.service.ts, we quickly pinpointed the API call causing the issue:

    This clarified the direction: doctors use the generic users/records endpoint instead of the doctor-specific one.

  2. Backend tracing: Following the trail into the Rails backend, from UsersController to UserService, and finally down to the core RecordService.

Step 2: Code Archaeology (Finding the Logic Flaw)

Section titled “Step 2: Code Archaeology (Finding the Logic Flaw)”

In RecordService.query_by_user_id_or_patient_id, we found an old snippet that looks “helpful” but is actually dangerous:

Logical reasoning: The comment shows that to accommodate historical dirty data (patient_id of 0), the query forcibly adds 0 to the filter. However, when a doctor (User A) views a patient (Patient B), the system queries: user_id = Doctor_A AND patient_id IN (Patient_B, 0)

This means that as long as there are records under that doctor with patient_id 0 (test data or orphan data that was not bound), they will mix into Patient B’s list.

Step 3: Data Falsification (Nailing the Bug)

Section titled “Step 3: Data Falsification (Nailing the Bug)”

To validate the reasoning, Antigravity did not guess. It wrote SQL to run “probe detection” in the SIT environment (integration test database).

Query 1: Does this doctor actually have “ghost data”?

Query 2: Simulating the bug logic

Query 3: Expected correct logic

Conclusion: Data leakage is real. The extra 2918 rows are exactly those patient_id=0 ghost records being wrongly pulled into Patient B’s page.

Fix and Takeaways

Section titled “Fix and Takeaways”

Once the root cause was found, the fix was obvious: when querying a specific patient (patient_id present), drop the 0 compatibility to keep isolation pure.

This case shows the unique value of an AI agent in software engineering:

  1. Go beyond the surface: Skip UI reproduction; restore business logic through code control flow.
  2. Data-driven: Use direct database access to build test cases that verify hypotheses.
  3. Precision strikes: In millions of lines of code, quickly home in on a few critical conditional checks.

For Antigravity, there is no “unreachable” site; only logic not yet parsed.

  • Google Antigravity

Fixing Bugs Without the User's Phone: An Antigravity Autonomous Debugging Case Study

Dec 11, 2025
Vibe Sparking

When a user reports “the lock screen can’t be tapped to enter the app when the phone font is set to maximum,” and you don’t have that phone model on hand, what do you do? This article records how Antigravity, using only the user’s screenshots and description, explored the codebase on its own, reasoned through the issue, and successfully shipped a fix.

Background

Section titled “Background”

In mobile app development, we often hit a tricky situation: a user-reported bug cannot be reproduced in the dev environment. Possible reasons include:

  • No test device of the same model
  • Unable to mirror the user’s specific system settings
  • The issue only appears under a particular combination of conditions

Traditional methods usually require remote debugging, screen-recording analysis, or outright buying/borrowing the device. Now, Antigravity’s autonomous debugging offers a new path.

Problem Description

Section titled “Problem Description”

Issue #169: A user reports that on a certain phone, when the system font is set to maximum, the lock screen cannot be tapped to enter the app.

User-provided information:

  • Device: Samsung Galaxy S20
  • Condition: System font set to maximum
  • Symptom: The “swipe up to enter home” area on the lock screen does not respond

The AI Diagnostic Process

Section titled “The AI Diagnostic Process”

Step 1: Understand the Problem Space

Section titled “Step 1: Understand the Problem Space”

Antigravity first analyzed the key phrases:

  • “font at maximum” -> involves system font scaling (textScaleFactor)
  • “cannot tap” -> likely a layout overflow making the interactive area inaccessible
  • “lock screen” -> need to locate lock screen-related code

Step 2: Code Exploration

Section titled “Step 2: Code Exploration”

The AI used multiple tools in parallel to explore the codebase:

Key findings:

Finding 1: The main app already guards against font scaling

Finding 2: The lock screen is displayed via Overlay

Step 3: Reasoning and Analysis

Section titled “Step 3: Reasoning and Analysis”

Based on the code review, the AI inferred the root cause:

Conclusion: The lock screen is inserted via Overlay.insert() and sits outside the app’s MediaQuery wrapper. Therefore:

  1. When the user sets the system font to maximum, the lock screen text scales up.
  2. The enlarged content overflows the visible area.
  3. The “enter home” swipe area is pushed off-screen, so the user cannot interact.

Step 4: Design the Fix

Section titled “Step 4: Design the Fix”

The fix is straightforward: add a dedicated MediaQuery guard to the lock screen.

Step 5: Verification

Section titled “Step 5: Verification”

Without physical hardware, the AI used static analysis to verify:

Results showed:

  • OK No syntax errors
  • OK No compilation errors
  • Warn Only expected deprecation warnings (consistent with existing code style)

Key Reasoning Insights from the AI

Section titled “Key Reasoning Insights from the AI”

Throughout the diagnosis, the AI demonstrated several critical reasoning skills:

1. Cross-File Correlation

Section titled “1. Cross-File Correlation”

Instead of looking at lock_screen.dart in isolation, the AI traced how the lock screen is displayed (in main.dart), and spotted the mismatch between Overlay and MediaQuery.

2. Framework-Aware Reasoning

Section titled “2. Framework-Aware Reasoning”

The AI understands Flutter’s widget tree: MediaQuery scope applies only to its subtree. Overlay is not part of that subtree, so it is not constrained by the app-wide setting.

3. Mapping User Scenarios to Code

Section titled “3. Mapping User Scenarios to Code”

From the user action “font at maximum,” the AI pinpointed the technical concept textScaleFactor and how it works in Flutter.

What We Learn from This Case

Section titled “What We Learn from This Case”

For Developers

Section titled “For Developers”
  1. Mind context inheritance when using Overlay: Overlay may not inherit the desired Theme/MediaQuery settings.
  2. Global configs must cover every entry point: If you want to disable font scaling, make sure all UI entry points are covered.
  3. Include accessibility in testing: Large fonts are a common accessibility requirement and should be in the test matrix.

For AI-Assisted Development

Section titled “For AI-Assisted Development”
  1. Enough context matters: User screenshots + problem description + codebase access = sufficient diagnostic info.
  2. Static analysis is an effective validation tool: Even without a runtime environment, it can verify correctness.
  3. Reasoning compensates for missing environments: Understanding framework mechanics beats simply running tests.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

This case shows a new paradigm for Antigravity’s autonomous debugging: reasoning-driven diagnosis based on code understanding.

Traditional debugging relies on the “reproduce -> observe -> modify -> verify” loop. When reproduction fails, the loop breaks.

Antigravity offers another path: “analyze code structure -> reason about the cause -> design a fix -> validate statically.” It does not replace traditional debugging, but serves as a powerful supplement when conditions are constrained.

Of course, final confirmation still requires testing on real devices. But the AI has already turned “searching for a needle in a haystack” into “precise pinpointing,” dramatically shortening time to resolution.

This article is based on Antigravity’s real diagnosis and fix for Issue #169 on December 11, 2025.

  • Google Antigravity

Decoding Antigravity: An Agentic Workflow from Screenshot to Code Fix

Dec 11, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Decoding Antigravity: An Agentic Workflow from Screenshot to Code Fix

Section titled “Decoding Antigravity: An Agentic Workflow from Screenshot to Code Fix”

In the traditional AI-assisted programming (Copilot) model, developers often have to act as “navigators”: you tell the AI “read this file,” “explain this code,” “write a function for me.” Through conversation, you steer the AI to finish the work step by step.

Antigravity represents the next generation of Agentic AI. It is no longer a passive Q&A bot but an “intelligent teammate” that can explore autonomously, reason proactively, and independently complete tasks in complex codebases.

This article uses a real bug-fix case to break down how Antigravity actually works.

1. Perception: More Than OCR (Perception)

Section titled “1. Perception: More Than OCR (Perception)”

Everything starts with user feedback.

Suppose a user submits an issue (e.g., ISSUE-182):

Title: [Weice] blood glucose/uric acid combo meter (a combined glucometer and uric acid analyzer) uploads blood glucose data, but the database does not save it Description: Call POST /api/v2/users/records.json with a payload containing blood_glucose and uric_acid. Checking the database shows only uric acid is stored; blood glucose is missing.

After receiving the task, Antigravity first performs full-context perception:

  • Read the issue description: extract key information (API path, parameter structure, error symptom).
  • Analyze the tech stack: identify it as a Rails API project (backend) plus a Flutter app (frontend).
  • Locate the environment: determine that beyond code, it needs Postgres and Loki MCP servers to check logs and data.

It constructs a “task graph”:

  • Goal: fix the missing uploaded data.
  • Entry point: backend API endpoint /api/v2/users/records.json.

2. Exploration: Reading the code like a senior engineer (Exploration)

Section titled “2. Exploration: Reading the code like a senior engineer (Exploration)”

Antigravity does not guess; it uses its toolchain for purposeful exploration.

Step 2.1 Route locating

Section titled “Step 2.1 Route locating”

It starts like a human engineer, locating the code entry via the API path.

  • Tool Call: grep_search(query: "records", path: "config/routes.rb")
  • Result: finds the route mapped to Api::V2::Users::RecordsController#create.

Step 2.2 Following the trail

Section titled “Step 2.2 Following the trail”

Next, it digs into the controller code.

  • Tool Call: view_file(path: "app/controllers/api/v2/users/records_controller.rb")
  • Analysis: the logic shows it calls a RecordService.new(params).save service class.

Step 2.3 Into the core logic

Section titled “Step 2.3 Into the core logic”

The heart of the problem usually hides in the business layer.

  • Tool Call: view_file(path: "app/services/record_service.rb")
  • Discovery: In RecordService, Antigravity might use view_file_outline to quickly map the method structure and find the data-processing logic:

3. Reasoning: Building a mental model (Reasoning)

Section titled “3. Reasoning: Building a mental model (Reasoning)”

At this point, Antigravity is not just “reading” code; it is running a thought simulation.

Facing the situation where blood_glucose is missing but uric_acid is stored, it quickly proposes several hypotheses:

  1. Hypothesis A: Was blood_glucose filtered out by valid_type?
  2. Hypothesis B: Did a validation error occur during DB write while the main transaction did not roll back?
  3. Hypothesis C: Is there a special filter for the [Weice] device type?

To validate the hypotheses, Antigravity proactively calls MCP tools to query real-time logs or the database:

  • Monitor: use loki_query to inspect API request logs and confirm the payload reached the server.
  • Check DB: use execute_sql to check the records table schema and confirm field definitions.

Combining code logic (static analysis) with runtime state (dynamic analysis), it may spot a line that looks harmless but is the real culprit:

“Aha!” - there is the root cause.

4. Execution: The precise scalpel (Action)

Section titled “4. Execution: The precise scalpel (Action)”

Once the issue is located, Antigravity enters Execution Mode. It is meticulous:

  1. Draft a plan: Antigravity generates an implementation_plan.md listing the files and specific change points.
  2. Request approval: It shows the plan to the user: “I found issue X and plan to modify file Y. Do you approve?”
  3. Perform the edits: After approval, it uses the replace_file_content tool to precisely replace the problematic code block instead of rewriting the whole file.

5. Verification: Not just run, but verify (Verification)

Section titled “5. Verification: Not just run, but verify (Verification)”

Shipping code is not the end. Antigravity knows the importance of testing the main path.

  • Automated tests: It runs rspec spec/services/record_service_spec.rb to ensure the bug is fixed without introducing regressions.
  • Generate a report: Finally, it creates a walkthrough.md with diffs and test-result screenshots to clearly show: “The problem is solved, and here is the evidence.”

Conclusion: From co-pilot to co-worker

Section titled “Conclusion: From co-pilot to co-worker”

Antigravity’s core value lies in agency.

  • It does not need you to feed it every line: give it a requirement, and it finds the relevant files itself.
  • It does not need you to act as its compiler: it runs tests, reads errors, and fixes them itself.
  • It is a closed loop: from discovering the issue to resolving it, it forms a complete workflow.

This is Antigravity - an AI partner that works alongside you, understands code and business context, and is built to solve problems.
